all_summaries: The paper introduces a novel approach to phenotyped Heart Failure (HF) patients using Dutch discharge letters to infer Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction (LVEF) classes (HFrEF, HFmrEF, HFpEF) through natural language processing (NLP) models, comparing interpretable models like Aug-Linear with black-box models such as BERT-based and transformer-based models. It evaluates the performance of these models on structured and unstructured data, demonstrating that Aug-Linear achieves competitive results with high interpretability, particularly in distinguishing HFrEF and HFpEF, while highlighting the importance of interpretability in clinical decision-making. The study also explores the challenges of labeling data with silver labels derived from structured data and clinical texts, and emphasizes the potential of unstructured data in enhancing HF phenotyping.

The paper introduces a novel approach to phenotype heart failure (HF) patients using Dutch discharge letters to infer left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) classes, comparing interpretable models like Aug-Linear with black-box models. It evaluates the performance of these models on structured and unstructured data, demonstrating that Aug-Linear achieves competitive results with high interpretability, especially when combining with structured data. The study highlights the importance of interpretability in clinical NLP, showing that Aug-Linear models provide explanations more aligned with clinical reasoning than post-hoc methods like SHAP and LIME. Key findings include improved classification accuracy and the effectiveness of using discharge letters for LVEF inference, with Aug-Linear models offering both high performance and explainability in HF phenotyping.
